div.p: V:Mr Stratford Canning, the British Minister had a Letter from the King of Great-Britain to present, announcing the birth of a daughter to the Duke of Clarence. I presented him to the President; at One O’Clock this day, when he delivered the Letter. Mr Crawford happened to call at the President’s about the same time and we met him there— Commodore Stewart and Mr William Tudor called together at the Office— Stewart is to sit upon a Court of Enquiry concerning Commodore James Barron, upon his application to be restored to his command in the Navy— Tudor, who is Mrs Stewart’s brother, and a man of good talents came with Stewart, and wishes to obtain some public employment— Mr Calhoun the Secretary of War called at the Office and brought a copy of his Instructions to General Jackson.

22. V. I removed from my writing Chamber, upon which the Carpenters are engaged in making repairs and in opening a door from the new part of my house, and wrote in the dining room below. I am now struggling to redeem the arrears of my diary; but write so slow; and with so much difficulty and pain that I fear I shall never effectually accomplish it. Mr Calhoun called at my house and I went to the Navy Department, to complete the arrangements for taking possession of the Florida’s. We have stipulated to transport the Spanish Officers and troops with their baggage to the Havanna, and by a liberal construction of the Article, have considered this engagement as including that of furnishing provisions for them on the passage. We have also engaged to provide an escort for them. The Secretary at War issues through the Quarter Master’s department, orders for hiring the transports and supplying the provisions, and the Secretary of the Navy issues the orders for the escort— They are all to be provided at two points; one for Pensacola, and the other for St. Augustine— I returned at O’Neil’s Hotel the visits of Commodore Stewart and W. Tudor; the latter of whom only I found at his lodgings. We had half an hours conversation, chiefly upon literary subjects. I was engaged the remainder of the day, in Office hours, in drafting a Note to the Baron Hyde de Neuville, upon the subject of the Negotiation with him.

23. V:Mr Luther Rice and Mr Obadiah B. Brown the Baptist Clergymen who had applied to me on the 8th. of December last for my Subscription to their Society for literary purposes, which I then declined came this day, and requested not a subscription, but a certificate or written recommendation of their Institution—which they have now curtailed into a College, and for which they have at the late Session of Congress obtained an Act of Incorporation by the name of the Columbian College. I told them that I regretted that I could not comply with their request, for two reasons— One that having declined upon Considerations which I had fully explained, subscribing to their Institution, I thought I could not with any propriety recommend with my name that for which I had not seen fit to give my money— The other was a general rule that I had prescribed to myself to give no written recommendations of this kind for any thing. I believed that things very useful would make their way without needing any recommendation; and if I should indulge myself in the practice of giving any recommendations, I should be bound to decline them whenever I should not approve the object for which the object would be required, or should not have a knowledge of its merits— Both these cases would lead to very awkward discussions upon special occasions— They led to unpleasant controversy. A general rule could give offence to none— These Gentlemen were of course not satisfied— Brown was far less urgent than Rice. He said if I had made it a general rule to give no written recommendations they could not urge it upon me now. Rice said that they had applied to the President who had also declined giving a written recommendation; but he had promised to write a private Letter to one of them expressing a favourable opinion of their undertaking, with permission to them to publish it— Rice further said that they had already collected subscriptions sufficient to enable them to open very shortly their College—that in a late tour through some of the Southern States, he had collected for eight successive weeks upwards of a thousand dollars a week; and their prospects were of the most flattering success. I told them that their general object the promotion of the education of youth had my hearty concurrence and good-wishes, as they must have those of every friend of humanity. Upon this they took their leave— It was one of those occasions upon which it is not in my nature to give graciousness to refusal, and I suppose the chilling coldness of my manner was more offensive than the refusal itself. I avoid at least with studied intention all displeasing words, but of the forbidding countenance and manner I never could divest myself— Before going to my Office, I called to see at his house W. S. Smith who is confined by illness to his chamber— Commodore Stewart and William Lee came to my Office— Attended an evening party at Coll. Tayloe’s.

24. IV:15. A Mr Taylor of Alexandria, came to the Office, on account of some claim. And Mr Columbus Fenwick, about his application for the appointment of Consul at Nantes. I am now employed upon the draft of a Letter to the Baron Hyde de Neuville, on the subject of a claim to exclusive privileges in the Ports of Louisiana for which there is a plausible colour, but only a colour in the 8th. Article of the Cession Treaty. This claim was first advanced by him in December 1817. and was then answered by me. He replied by a long Note insisting upon it in June 1818. The discussion was then useless, and I left this second Note unanswered— When the commercial Negotiation was commenced last Summer with Mr Gallatin the French Government immediately brought forward this claim; and as he was not instructed upon it they made it a pretence for transferring the Negotiation to this place, and for sending back de Neuville— It will make a volume of diplomatic altercation to no earthly purpose. We spent this Evening at the Baron’s House; at the weekly evening party of his Lady— I lost two games at Chess; playing with Mr Payne Todd.

25. VI: I went with Dr. Thornton this Morning to the Quaker Meeting. There were from forty to fifty men present, and about as many females. We sat nearly two hours in perfect silence— No moving of the Spirit, and I seldom in the course of my life passed two hours more wearily— Perhaps from not having been enured to this mode of public worship, I found myself quite unable to reduce my mind to that musing meditation which forms the essence of this form of devotion— It was rambling from this world to the next, and from the next back to this, chance-directed, and curious to know what was really passing in the minds of those around me. I asked Doctor Thornton after we came out what he had been thinking of while we had been there— He said he did not know; he had been much inclined to sleep. Solitude and Silence are natural allies, and social Silence may be properly allied with social labour— But social meditation is an incongruity— I felt on coming from this Meeting as if I had wasted precious time— Passed the remainder of the day at home, assiduously writing. Mrs Adams spent the Evening at W. S. Smith’s— He is yet confined to his chamber.

26. V: I had sent to the President on Saturday Evening my draft of a Letter to the Baron Hyde de Neuville on the claim of France under the Louisiana cession Treaty; and I received this Morning a Note from the President, directing a Cabinet Meeting at his house at twelve O’Clock this day— It was accordingly held; and attended by all the members of the Administration except Mr Wirt the Attorney General, who is confined by illness to his house. My draft was a reply to de Neuville’s Letter of 6. June 1818. Both were read, and both contain elaborate counter-arguments. I requested that my draft might be severely scrutinized, particularly with regard to the ground of argument which it assumed— The French claim has a strong colour of plausibility, and it was important that we should in resisting it take no stand from which we might hereafter find it necessary to withdraw— There was no diversity of opinion, upon the discussion. There are two untenable points in the claim—one that it is broader than the stipulation upon which it is founded—the other, that upon a promise of equal favour it claims gratuitously that which has been granted to others for an equivalent. Mr Crawford made a sound objection to one expression in the draft, as too harsh and I immediately altered it— The rest was approved. But the Baron de Neuville appears determined to pick a quarrel upon another affair— The seizure of the Apollon in St. Mary’s river— Although he came without any Instructions from his Government on the subject he has repeatedly hinted that satisfaction must be given to France concerning it before he can agree to any arrangement of a merely commercial interest. He wrote me a Note some weeks since to enquire whether another vessel, called the Edmond, which grounded in the attempt to enter St. Augustine, and then went and entered as in distress at Amelia Island, could there take in a Cargo from the United States without being molested— This has led to a correspondence in one Note of which de Neuville asserts that a grave error has been committed, referring to the case of the Apollon, and meaning, by the American Government— I am to reply also to this Note— The Edmond has not been allowed to ship goods from the United States into Amelia-Island; but the disposition of the President and most especially of Mr Crawford is to give up the Apollon— She was seized under an order from the Treasury of 6. May 1818. but they seem to think that order was not warranted by Law— I think otherwise, but the District Attorney in Georgia, Habersham countenances the opinion that there is no law to reach the case. It had been determined after the seizure of the Apollon to have the case tried in the District and Circuit Courts, and if the decision in them should be against the Government to bring it up by appeal to the Supreme Court— The final decision could not have been had in less than two or three years, and in the mean time the fraudulent use of the Florida
territory could not have been made for evading and defeating the Laws of the Union— The main object of this profligate scheme would have been disconcerted, and if the Captain and owners of the Apollon must finally be indemnified by the Government, it would cost only a trifling sum in comparison with the heavy loss to the public by the success and impunity of the project. But since the ratification by Spain of the Florida Treaty, the same object will be attained by another process. The boundary is transferred from the St. Mary’s to the Sabine river— Florida becomes our own and offers no longer a lurking hole for foreign smugglers. There is no motive for keeping the decision upon the case of the Apollon suspended; and as the legality of the Treasury order of 6. May 1818 is questionable, it was now concluded that I should direct the District Attorney in Georgia to dismiss the appeal from the decision of the District Court, which was only a decree pro forma, and order the restoration of the Apollon to her Captain, leaving him to his action against the Collector for indemnity— I was convinced this would in no wise satisfy de Neuville, and only acquiesced in, without approving the measure— I am also to enclose to de Neuville copies of the papers communicated with my answer to General Vives on the case of the Apollon.

27. IV:45.Mr Calhoun called this morning at my house with General Preston of Virginia; who informed me that he was desirous of obtaining hereafter an appointment under the general Government. This Gentleman has been Governor of the State of Virginia, and might have been a General in the Army, but for some question about rank— He has just received a temporary appointment as Commissioner under a recent Treaty with the Creek Indians, and his intimation to me was that as it was expected General Jackson did not intend to hold long the Office of Governor of the Florida’s, in case of his resignation, Mr Preston would be willing to succeed him— But he said it was as object of peculiar concern to him, and which he wished might be considered before any appointment should be conferred upon him, that he wished for no office, in which the Government should not be entirely satisfied that his services would yield to the public an ample equivalent for his appointment— This is some thing like asking for a favour and giving notice that it will not be received as a favour— Independence asks no favours— It will be woo’d and not unsought be won. The President called at the Office to speak about the appointment of the Commissioners under the Florida Treaty— He has given up the idea of appointing C. A. Rodney, and Chapman Johnson; and now spoke of H. Wheaton of New-York, and H. L. White of Tennessee. He said that Mr Johnson was fully qualified for the Office, but as the recommendations for him and those for Mr Hay seemed to have been given as in a sort of mutual opposition to each other, he had thought best as he did not appoint Mr Hay, to avoid also the appointment of his rival. To Wheaton he said the only objection was, that he belonged to one of the large cities where the principal losses had been sustained— If one Commissioner should be selected from one of them, and none from another, the sufferers of the neglected city would complain of partiality, and be jealous of the decisions— And he asked me if this was not my opinion— I said it was a view of the Subject deserving great consideration— But there was also another view of it, which should not be passed over— All the difficult questions which will be presented for the decision of the Commissioners, will be questions of commercial or maritime Law— Questions in which the Lawyers of the large Cities are peculiarly conversant, and Mr Wheaton probably more than any other man in the Union— The lawyers of the interior however learned and well qualified in other respects would not be so familiar with that so familiar with that special branch of the Law, and for that reason probably their decisions might be less satisfactory to the Sufferers— Nor did I think there would be any solid reason for complaint if one Commissioner should be taken from one of the Cities, and none from the others—the important question would be, the qualifications of
the person selected; and if they should be eminently suited to the appointment, as in the case of Mr Wheaton they certainly would be, I thought the little jealousies of rival cities might safely be disregarded— There was a Mr Alvey came to the Office having a claim upon the Spanish Government, for certain provisions taken by force from him for the supply of Spanish troops in South-America. General John Mason also came, and stating that he was the Agent of many claimants under the Florida Treaty requested that he might have access to their documents filed in the Department of State: to which I assented.

28. IV.Mr F. C. Fenwick was at the Office again upon his solicitation for the appointment of Consul at Nantes and Alexander Scott of Georgetown to importune for that of Secretary to the Commission of Claims under the Florida Treaty— The act of Congress requires that the Secretary should be conversant with the French and Spanish languages— Scott who has some knowledge of French, but scarcely any of Spanish still presses to be appointed, and now gravely came and shewed me a Letter from a Spanish South American named Orrea, now at Philadelphia. Scott’s proposal was that he should send for this Mr Orrea to come and live with him; and being perfectly familiar with our language as well as with his own, that he should be Scott’s proxy for every thing in which the knowledge of Spanish might be required— I told him I thought this would not answer the requirement of the Law. I made the draft of a second Letter to the Baron Hyde de Neuville; this being upon the seizure of the Apollon. Dr Thornton passed the Evening with us, and beat me at Chess.

29. VI: I received this morning a Note from the President, returning the draft of the Letter to the French Minister, with suggestions of a few alterations, all of which I adopted, though in one instance with reluctance— In his Letter, referring to our proceedings in the case of the Apollon, he had asserted that a grave error had been committed— This imputation of error, to a Government, by a foreign Minister, accredited to it, is so indecorous and offensive that I had answered it in the draft, more sharply than the President thinks necessary— He alters it therefore to “you appear to assume as a fact, what this Government can never admit, namely that a grave error has been committed &c.” there is a feebleness and a symptom of hesitation in this turn of phrase, which de Neuville will seize upon, to push us hard upon that point. In the draft, I had turned the attack upon himself, and put him upon the defensive, for the imputation— I sent him this day the long answer to his Letter of 6. June 1818 upon the Louisiana Claim, and also received a Note from him— The President in his Letter of this Morning also informed me, that he had concluded upon appointing Hugh Lawson White of Tennessee, William King of Maine, and John W. Green of Virginia, Commissioners of Claims, under the Florida Treaty. I directed Commissions to be issued for them accordingly. Spent the Evening at W. S. Smith’s, at Chess— He is recovering from his illness.

30. VI:45.Mr Josiah Meigs the Commissioner of the Land Office, called this morning at my Office with a Mr Parr, an Englishman, a native and inhabitant of the town of Boston in Lincolnshire, who has been some time travelling in the United States— He told me he had lately been at our Boston, and was highly gratified with the reception and hospitality which he had experienced there; much of which he ascribed, I have no doubt truly, to the name of the place whence he came— Boston in New-England was originally named after Boston in Lincolnshire, because it was the birth-place of Mr Cotton the Minister, and probably of many other original settlers of Massachusetts— But two hundred years wash out all the colour of kindred blood— The two Bostons have become so strange to each other that this Mr Parr, was the first English Bostonian I ever met with, and I myself felt in
in that circumstance a link of association with him that I should not have felt for an Englishman from any other place— He is about returning to England; and hinted the intention of publishing some account of his travels in this Country. Mr Alvey was at the Office again about his claim upon the Spanish Government; and Fenwick about his Consulate— Mr Andrew Way called and brought me a new Deed of the House and Lots in F. Street, executed by himself and his father— I was at the President’s, and met there Mr George Hay and Mr Calhoun.

31. VI: A rainy day— Mr Alvey came again to the Office, and was furnished with a Letter, recommending him and his claim to Thomas L. L. Brent, the Charge d’Affaires at Madrid— I received a Letter from the President relating to some embarrassing applications in behalf of William Gracie of New-York. He married a daughter of Oliver Wolcott now Governor of Connecticut—but she died a year or two since— Charles King, son of Rufus the Senator from New-York, married Gracie’s Sister. I received a few days ago a Letter from Charles King, saying that Gracie was going to France, to pass some time, and expressing the wish that he might be attached to the American Legation there; and a Letter from Gracie himself offering to take despatches. The President had also received a Letter from Governor Wolcott requesting the appointment of Gracie as Secretary of Legation, and I have one from him, urging the interposition of the Government again in behalf of the claim of Archibald Gracie and Co. for the seizure of a vessel and Cargo of theirs at Antwerp— The President is apprehensive that both the special interposition, and the attaching of Gracie to the Legation at Paris would be displeasing to Mr Gallatin, and objectionable to other claimants upon France, as shewing partial favour to Gracie’s claim in preference to others equally well founded— He directs me therefore if I give Gracie any Letter to Mr Gallatin to write it with special circumspection; and I wrote to Gracie and Gallatin accordingly— I received from the Baron Hyde de Neuville a Letter in reply to mine upon the Louisiana claim. Without abandoning the ground of his first demand, he now assumes another— His first claim was that French vessels should be received in the Ports of Louisiana, paying no higher duties than British vessels pay in all the Ports of the Union— He now claims that if they are not entitled to this, they should at least be exempted from the extra-tonnage duty which is not paid by Nations with when we have no Treaty— This claim is more plausible but not more sound than the other.

Day. The range of my rising hour through the Month has been from four to seven O’Clock. The average Five and thirty-six minutes. From that time till Noon I am engaged in writing with the interval of an hour for breakfast; and almost always an hour or two wasted upon reading and assorting Newspapers. The breach in this Diary of four Months and a half by the indispensable occupation of the Morning hours upon other writing, threatens to be irreparable— Yet I have resumed it, and am labouring to retrieve the lost Time— About Noon I repair to my Office, where I am employed upon its current business until 6. in the Evening; calling when occasion requires at the President’s; and attending at the Meetings of the Members of the Administration there, which are likewise occasional. We dine between six and seven, after which I read Newspapers, pay or receive neighbourly visits, and now within these few days, revise the proof Sheets of my Report upon Weights and Measures. Between ten and eleven is the hour of retirement.
